fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Riemannian manifold M with metric g, if the sectional curvature at a point \operatorname {sec}(v, w) is bounded between \kappa _1 and \kappa _2, we can make some bounds on the curvature tensor, essentially by linear algebra. This is discussed in section 6 from Sur quelques variétés riemanniennes suffisamment pincées.

Take an orthonormal set of vectors X_i, X_j, X_k, X_l. The sectional curvature is given by \operatorname {sec}(X_i, X_j) = R(X_i, X_j, X_j, X_i). Let a^2 + b^2 = c^2 + d^2 = 1, then we can generate a family of inequalities \kappa _1 < \operatorname {sec}(a X_i + b X_j, c X_k + d X_l) < \kappa _2. Let us write \operatorname {sec}_{i j} for \operatorname {sec}(X_i, X_j). Then we can expand the definition to get \begin {aligned} \kappa _1 &< a^2 c^2 \operatorname {sec}_{ik} &&+ 2 a^2 c d R_{ikli} &&+ a^2 d^2 \operatorname {sec}_{il} \\ &+ 2 a b c^2 R_{ikkj} &&+ 2 a b c d (R_{iklj} + R_{ilkj}) &&+ 2 a b d^2 R_{illj} \\ &+ b^2 c^2 \operatorname {sec}_{jk} &&+ 2 b^2 c d R_{jklj} &&+ b^2 d^2 \operatorname {sec}_{jl} &< \kappa _2. \end {aligned}

In the case (c, d) = (1, 0), the inequality expands to \kappa _1 < a^2 \operatorname {sec}_{i k} + 2 a b R_{ikkj} + b^2 \operatorname {sec}_{j k} < \kappa _2. From the AM–GM inequality, we can take the appropriate signs for a and b to get |R_{ikkj}| < \sqrt {(\operatorname {sec}_{i k} - \kappa _1)(\operatorname {sec}_{j k} - \kappa _1)} and |R_{ikkj}| < \sqrt {(\operatorname {sec}_{i k} - \kappa _2)(\operatorname {sec}_{j k} - \kappa _2)}. We can also just take a = b = \pm 1/\sqrt {2} to get coarser bounds.

Now for the general case. Taking b = ±b', d = ±d' and summing the two inequalities, we cancel out four of the terms. Now take a \mapsto -a and permute (j, k, l) \mapsto (l, j, k) to get a new inequality. Taking the sum we now have \begin {aligned} 2\kappa _1 <&\quad a^2 c^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{ik} + \operatorname {sec}_{ij}) + a^2 d^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{il} + \operatorname {sec}_{ik}) & \\ & + b^2 c^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{jk} + \operatorname {sec}_{lj}) + b^2 d^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{jl} + \operatorname {sec}_{lk}) & \\ & + 2 a b c d (R_{iklj} + R_{ilkj} - R_{ijkl} - R_{ikjl}) & < 2\kappa _2. \end {aligned} The last term can be reduced to -6 abcd R_{ljki} by the symmetries of the curvature tensor. AM–GM inequality now gives a rich set of bounds. Finally, we take a = b = c = d = 1/\sqrt {2} up to a sign. Let S be the sum of all the sectional curvatures involved. Then we have 2\kappa _1 < 2 S ± \frac {3}{2} |R_{ljki}| < 2\kappa _2. Therefore we have |R_{ljki}| < \frac {2}{3} (\kappa _2 - \kappa _1). And of course, if we start with non-strict pinching, we get analogous non-strict bounds.
